comments:
Finance 219 focuses on international financial markets and exchange rates. Topics include pricing in the foreign currency and Eurocurrency markets, use of forward exchange for hedging, short term returns and market efficiency in the international money markets, foreign currency options, international capital asset pricing, pricing of foreign currency bonds, currency swaps, Eurocurrency syndicated loans, foreign currency financing and exposure management.

The consensus feedback on this course with Professor Evans was unenthusiastic. However, several students described the course material as “interesting” and “very useful,” and one student noted that the structure, homework, and assignments were “highly suitable.” 

Many students expressed that they did not feel like they could connect with the professor, who was often unable to understand questions asked in class. Students indicated that they would have liked the professor to be more approachable and accessible. One student noted that the professor was rather knowledgeable about the material, but did not take the time out to adequately explain tougher concepts. Another student mentioned, “The professor was initially engaging,” but as the semester progressed, “his way of instructing was not very easy to understand.” 

Students widely believed that the grading system could have been improved and lacked consistency. Furthermore, most students seemed to be dissatisfied with the coverage and format of exams. One student proposed that Finance 206 effectively presented similar material and more.
